awd_titl_txt: Scholars Award: A History of Hunger: Agricultural Science, State, and Modernization
awd_abstract_narration:
Relations between external expertise and internal agricultural practices have been evolving throughout the twentieth century because of the drive to use science for enhancing food production and mitigating "hunger.? This project will study the particular framing of the problem of hunger by policy makers and state officials. It will explain how views and strategies of hunger impacted the effort toward modernization of agriculture in colonial and postcolonial India by Americans. Focusing on statist measures, expertise, and the experience of elites and subalterns this project will highlight efforts that tailored scientific knowledge specifically to the ends of production and neglected questions of distribution. The project will illustrate how the debate between production versus distribution strategies shaped the appropriation of American technologies. It will address scientific modernization from the domain of the political, the social, and the ecological. It will also provide an occasion to explore the convergences and disjunctures of differing stakeholders visions? of progress and the impact on technology use and practice. 

Historians of modern India have continued to explore the hows and whys of the arrested course of agricultural development in the twentieth-century. The existing scholarship characteristically relies on two core assumptions. On the one hand is the central belief of modernization theory that removal of concrete obstacles and impediments would lead to a self-perpetuating course of modernization becoming evident in the well-being of the masses. On the other hand, postcolonial scholarship in South Asian historiography continues to draw attention to the intransigence of subaltern life and consciousness that is arguably incommensurable with the logic of capitalist development. Scholars have highlighted the role of expert regime in agriculture to question the boundless power of experts and the state. In that regard this project explores the impact of the colonial moment and the American moment in the building of an expert grid in agriculture. The book argues that the agenda of technocratic modernization was engaged by groups with diverse political aims and social agenda, and connects that process of engagement with questions of rural inequality.  It illustrates this interaction while exploring two sets of records in the United States and India. On the one hand, it focusses on the work by American Presbyterian missionaries, Point Four technical and social scientific experts, and the agriculture faculty from American public land grant universities in India. On the other hand, it explores the efforts launched by nationalists and the national state in India for reviving agriculture and rural community.

A History of the Green Revolution in India

 

In the mid-1960s India took a decisive turn towards productive agriculture by embracing high yielding variety seeds (or HYVs) of wheat and paddy developed by Rockefeller Foundation’s breeders, an initiative that came to be flagged as the “green revolution” in India’s pursuit of productivity. The onset of the green revolution has been identified as the ultimate marker of modernization of India’s agriculture. This project makes the claim that the HYV crops in the flourishing river basins of India came at the end of a long arc of developments whose origins lay in colonial times. Resisting the idea of any “revolution” in deference to a principle of historical build up and precedent, the research takes a long view of the process of agrarian change in India that crossed paths with the nation’s colonial history, partition and displacement, and consequent infrastructural rebuilding, rolled into the regional history of northwestern India.

            The floodplains of Indus and the Ganges and Yamuna in the north emerged as distinct agrarian regions under the raj with the colonial state backing the construction of canals and productive agriculture. As the nation was partitioned, these very zones were settled by incoming refugees from West Pakistan on the fertile lands left behind by Muslim evacuees, and in the newly cleared Himalayan sub-montane region of Terai. These areas further experienced state-backed efforts at building productive communities that continued with added emphasis in creating infrastructures of agricultural development, from roads and electric lines to facilitation of land consolidation and provision of cooperative credit. The passage of land and agricultural reforms and efforts at technocratic resolutions went hand in hand. The expanding United States-India collaborations in the 1950s and 60s in the field of agricultural expertise and in creation of agricultural universities, the latter modeled after the land grant institutions in America, was a striking feature of these decades. Northwestern India had been primed to receive the HYVs when they became available at Rockefeller’s seed development project in Mexico. When India announced a new agricultural strategy around Mexican HYVs between 1964 and 1966, freeing further resources for subsidies and offering incentivized prices, the farmers of northwestern regions were most ready to embrace them.

            This project discloses the history of the green revolution as a contested process of modernization. The ecological harm and social disharmony in India’s northwest has been pinned on the green revolution in social scientific literature and in activist rhetoric. On multiple occasions, policymakers, ideologues, and experts in India had to make difficult choices between filling the food deficit gap versus spreading scarce resources for achieving wider growth; between saving the Himalayan submontane grasslands versus turning them into beds of arable lands. This project highlights the historical shaping of those choices.
